{"file_name":"sunset.svg","content":"<svg width="800" height="600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <linearGradient id="sunrise" x1="0" y1="0" x2="0" y2="1">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:orange; stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:purple; stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
  </defs>
  <rect width="100%" height="100%" fill="url(#sunrise)" />

  <!-- Mountains -->
  <polygon points="50,550 200,400 300,450 400,400 500,550" fill="#8B4513" />
  <polygon points="50,550 200,400 300,450 400,400 500,550" fill="#5C4033" />

  <!-- Sun rays -->
  <line x1="700" y1="100" x2="800" y2="200" stroke="yellow" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="700" y1="150" x2="800" y2="250" stroke="yellow" stroke-width="2"/>
  <circle cx="700" cy="100" r="30" fill="yellow"/>
</svg>"}

<think>
Okay, let's see. The user wanted an SVG of a sunset through the mountains and had it included in an HTML file.

First, I needed to create the SVG. I used the create_file function to generate sunset.svg with the appropriate XML content. The SVG has a gradient for the sunset and polygons for the mountains. Then, I made sure to add the sun rays with lines and a circle.

Next, I had to create the HTML file. Using another create_file call, I wrote index.html which includes a title, a heading, and an image tag linking to the SVG. The user mentioned making sure it's visible in index.html, so embedding the SVG directly wasn't an optionâ€”using an external file was better for separation.

I should check if the HTML is correctly referencing the SVG. The img src points to sunset.svg, which should be in the same directory. Also, the SVG dimensions are set, so it should display properly. The mountains are represented with two polygons to give a layered effect. The sun rays are simple lines and a circle for a basic sunrise look.

Everything seems set. The user can open index.html in a browser, and it should show the sunset image. No errors in the tool responses, so I think that's all.
</think>

The SVG file `sunset.svg` has been created with a gradient background simulating a sunset and polygons representing mountain peaks. The HTML file `index.html` has been created to display this SVG image. 

To view the result, open `index.html` in a web browser. The image should show a sunset over mountain ranges with simple rays emanating from the sun. Let me know if you'd like adjustments!
